comment: I don't recall ever seeing Polgar play 1. c4, so this ought to be interesting. When these two first met in tournaments Polgar won handily, then Shirov moved ahead and Polgar has been working hard to catch up. This tournament shows some of the results of that work.
Though a popular set-up (nowadays) I usually avoid developing a piece where it will be blocked (as Bg7 is blocked by Pe5) .

moves: 1. c4 e5 2. g3 g6 3. Bg2 Bg7 4. Nc3 Nf6 5. Nf3 d6 6. O-O O-O 7. d4
comment: Now it's just transposed to a King's Indian Defense, Fianchetto Variation which is still considered good for White, though the players involved make the difference. In this case Shirov as Black should be up to the task.

moves: 1. c4 e5 2. g3 g6 3. Bg2 Bg7 4. Nc3 Nf6 5. Nf3 d6 6. O-O O-O 7. d4 Nbd7 8. Qc2
comment: defending Nc3 to prepare b2-b3, Bc1-b2 and clearing the d-file to align Rd1 with Qd8

moves: 1. c4 e5 2. g3 g6 3. Bg2 Bg7 4. Nc3 Nf6 5. Nf3 d6 6. O-O O-O 7. d4 Nbd7 8. Qc2 Re8 9. Rd1 exd4
comment: Shirov changes the direction of the game and leaves Qd8 a bit cramped.

moves: 1. c4 e5 2. g3 g6 3. Bg2 Bg7 4. Nc3 Nf6 5. Nf3 d6 6. O-O O-O 7. d4 Nbd7 8. Qc2 Re8 9. Rd1 exd4 10. Nxd4 a5 11. e4 Nc5 12. f3
comment: Often h2-h3 is used to guard g4, but in this case Pf3 defends Pe4 and guards g4. Later on it might advance further and Pg3 won't have been weakened. It's hard to say at this point whether it's especially better.

moves: 1. c4 e5 2. g3 g6 3. Bg2 Bg7 4. Nc3 Nf6 5. Nf3 d6 6. O-O O-O 7. d4 Nbd7 8. Qc2 Re8 9. Rd1 exd4 10. Nxd4 a5 11. e4 Nc5 12. f3 c6
comment: Finally Shirov activates his queen at the cost of weakening Pd6. A lot of games have been won with the Black pieces from this opening and many have been tense dramatic struggles.

moves: 1. c4 e5 2. g3 g6 3. Bg2 Bg7 4. Nc3 Nf6 5. Nf3 d6 6. O-O O-O 7. d4 Nbd7 8. Qc2 Re8 9. Rd1 exd4 10. Nxd4 a5 11. e4 Nc5 12. f3 c6 13. Be3 Qe7 14. Bf2
comment: It's easier to retreat off the e-file than to defend Be3.

moves: 1. c4 e5 2. g3 g6 3. Bg2 Bg7 4. Nc3 Nf6 5. Nf3 d6 6. O-O O-O 7. d4 Nbd7 8. Qc2 Re8 9. Rd1 exd4 10. Nxd4 a5 11. e4 Nc5 12. f3 c6 13. Be3 Qe7 14. Bf2 Nfd7 15. b3 Ne5
comment: White's pawns are pretty safe, but her pieces will have to be activated and brought into the battle in a more aggressive way, as the game progresses, if she's to win.

moves: 1. c4 e5 2. g3 g6 3. Bg2 Bg7 4. Nc3 Nf6 5. Nf3 d6 6. O-O O-O 7. d4 Nbd7 8. Qc2 Re8 9. Rd1 exd4 10. Nxd4 a5 11. e4 Nc5 12. f3 c6 13. Be3 Qe7 14. Bf2 Nfd7 15. b3 Ne5 16. h3 Ned7 17. Rd2 Bh6 18. Re2 f6 19. f4
comment: White creeps forward...

moves: 1. c4 e5 2. g3 g6 3. Bg2 Bg7 4. Nc3 Nf6 5. Nf3 d6 6. O-O O-O 7. d4 Nbd7 8. Qc2 Re8 9. Rd1 exd4 10. Nxd4 a5 11. e4 Nc5 12. f3 c6 13. Be3 Qe7 14. Bf2 Nfd7 15. b3 Ne5 16. h3 Ned7 17. Rd2 Bh6 18. Re2 f6 19. f4 Nf8
comment: Black crouches in a kind of Hedgehog formation.

moves: 1. c4 e5 2. g3 g6 3. Bg2 Bg7 4. Nc3 Nf6 5. Nf3 d6 6. O-O O-O 7. d4 Nbd7 8. Qc2 Re8 9. Rd1 exd4 10. Nxd4 a5 11. e4 Nc5 12. f3 c6 13. Be3 Qe7 14. Bf2 Nfd7 15. b3 Ne5 16. h3 Ned7 17. Rd2 Bh6 18. Re2 f6 19. f4 Nf8 20. Rd1 Bd7 21. Ree1 Rad8 22. a3 Bc8 23. b4 axb4 24. axb4 Nce6 25. Nde2
comment: At this point it's hard to say what White's plan is, besides keeping Shirov restrained and cramped. The open a-file might be of some use, but the center might become active again in a moment, so it seems to be only a slight advantage to White.

moves: 1. c4 e5 2. g3 g6 3. Bg2 Bg7 4. Nc3 Nf6 5. Nf3 d6 6. O-O O-O 7. d4 Nbd7 8. Qc2 Re8 9. Rd1 exd4 10. Nxd4 a5 11. e4 Nc5 12. f3 c6 13. Be3 Qe7 14. Bf2 Nfd7 15. b3 Ne5 16. h3 Ned7 17. Rd2 Bh6 18. Re2 f6 19. f4 Nf8 20. Rd1 Bd7 21. Ree1 Rad8 22. a3 Bc8 23. b4 axb4 24. axb4 Nce6 25. Nde2 Qc7 26. Qb3 Kh8 27. Rc1
comment: aligning with Qc7 and possibly preparing Nc3-d5

moves: 1. c4 e5 2. g3 g6 3. Bg2 Bg7 4. Nc3 Nf6 5. Nf3 d6 6. O-O O-O 7. d4 Nbd7 8. Qc2 Re8 9. Rd1 exd4 10. Nxd4 a5 11. e4 Nc5 12. f3 c6 13. Be3 Qe7 14. Bf2 Nfd7 15. b3 Ne5 16. h3 Ned7 17. Rd2 Bh6 18. Re2 f6 19. f4 Nf8 20. Rd1 Bd7 21. Ree1 Rad8 22. a3 Bc8 23. b4 axb4 24. axb4 Nce6 25. Nde2 Qc7 26. Qb3 Kh8 27. Rc1 Qf7 28. Na4
comment: After this it looks like Ne2 might go to c3 while Na4 then becomes the awkward piece which might go to b6, c5 (if Pd6 moves) or b2.

moves: 1. c4 e5 2. g3 g6 3. Bg2 Bg7 4. Nc3 Nf6 5. Nf3 d6 6. O-O O-O 7. d4 Nbd7 8. Qc2 Re8 9. Rd1 exd4 10. Nxd4 a5 11. e4 Nc5 12. f3 c6 13. Be3 Qe7 14. Bf2 Nfd7 15. b3 Ne5 16. h3 Ned7 17. Rd2 Bh6 18. Re2 f6 19. f4 Nf8 20. Rd1 Bd7 21. Ree1 Rad8 22. a3 Bc8 23. b4 axb4 24. axb4 Nce6 25. Nde2 Qc7 26. Qb3 Kh8 27. Rc1 Qf7 28. Na4 Nc7 29. Nb6 Qg8 30. Nxc8 Rxc8 31. Qc2
comment: Qb3 was undefended and she wanted to avoid complications stemming from ...b7-b5.

moves: 1. c4 e5 2. g3 g6 3. Bg2 Bg7 4. Nc3 Nf6 5. Nf3 d6 6. O-O O-O 7. d4 Nbd7 8. Qc2 Re8 9. Rd1 exd4 10. Nxd4 a5 11. e4 Nc5 12. f3 c6 13. Be3 Qe7 14. Bf2 Nfd7 15. b3 Ne5 16. h3 Ned7 17. Rd2 Bh6 18. Re2 f6 19. f4 Nf8 20. Rd1 Bd7 21. Ree1 Rad8 22. a3 Bc8 23. b4 axb4 24. axb4 Nce6 25. Nde2 Qc7 26. Qb3 Kh8 27. Rc1 Qf7 28. Na4 Nc7 29. Nb6 Qg8 30. Nxc8 Rxc8 31. Qc2 Nd7 32. Red1 Bf8 33. Bd4 Ra8 34. h4
comment: This could be to free Bg2 or to threaten h4-h5xg6 to create an attack on the h-file. At this point it might seem to White that trading pieces (such as Rc1-a1) is risky because there are several weak pawns which need defenders.

moves: 1. c4 e5 2. g3 g6 3. Bg2 Bg7 4. Nc3 Nf6 5. Nf3 d6 6. O-O O-O 7. d4 Nbd7 8. Qc2 Re8 9. Rd1 exd4 10. Nxd4 a5 11. e4 Nc5 12. f3 c6 13. Be3 Qe7 14. Bf2 Nfd7 15. b3 Ne5 16. h3 Ned7 17. Rd2 Bh6 18. Re2 f6 19. f4 Nf8 20. Rd1 Bd7 21. Ree1 Rad8 22. a3 Bc8 23. b4 axb4 24. axb4 Nce6 25. Nde2 Qc7 26. Qb3 Kh8 27. Rc1 Qf7 28. Na4 Nc7 29. Nb6 Qg8 30. Nxc8 Rxc8 31. Qc2 Nd7 32. Red1 Bf8 33. Bd4 Ra8 34. h4 Qf7 35. Bh3 Ne6 36. Bb2 Nb6 37. Nd4 Nc7 38. Nf3 Kg8 39. e5
comment: She chose a good moment for this advance; after Black had moved toward the queen-side and weakened his control of e5. It might have also been a 40-move time control.

moves: 1. c4 e5 2. g3 g6 3. Bg2 Bg7 4. Nc3 Nf6 5. Nf3 d6 6. O-O O-O 7. d4 Nbd7 8. Qc2 Re8 9. Rd1 exd4 10. Nxd4 a5 11. e4 Nc5 12. f3 c6 13. Be3 Qe7 14. Bf2 Nfd7 15. b3 Ne5 16. h3 Ned7 17. Rd2 Bh6 18. Re2 f6 19. f4 Nf8 20. Rd1 Bd7 21. Ree1 Rad8 22. a3 Bc8 23. b4 axb4 24. axb4 Nce6 25. Nde2 Qc7 26. Qb3 Kh8 27. Rc1 Qf7 28. Na4 Nc7 29. Nb6 Qg8 30. Nxc8 Rxc8 31. Qc2 Nd7 32. Red1 Bf8 33. Bd4 Ra8 34. h4 Qf7 35. Bh3 Ne6 36. Bb2 Nb6 37. Nd4 Nc7 38. Nf3 Kg8 39. e5 dxe5 40. fxe5 Ra2 41. Qb3 Rxb2 42. Qxb2 Nxc4 43. e6 Nxb2 44. exf7+ Kxf7 45. Rd7+ Re7 46. Rc2
comment: costs a pawn

moves: 1. c4 e5 2. g3 g6 3. Bg2 Bg7 4. Nc3 Nf6 5. Nf3 d6 6. O-O O-O 7. d4 Nbd7 8. Qc2 Re8 9. Rd1 exd4 10. Nxd4 a5 11. e4 Nc5 12. f3 c6 13. Be3 Qe7 14. Bf2 Nfd7 15. b3 Ne5 16. h3 Ned7 17. Rd2 Bh6 18. Re2 f6 19. f4 Nf8 20. Rd1 Bd7 21. Ree1 Rad8 22. a3 Bc8 23. b4 axb4 24. axb4 Nce6 25. Nde2 Qc7 26. Qb3 Kh8 27. Rc1 Qf7 28. Na4 Nc7 29. Nb6 Qg8 30. Nxc8 Rxc8 31. Qc2 Nd7 32. Red1 Bf8 33. Bd4 Ra8 34. h4 Qf7 35. Bh3 Ne6 36. Bb2 Nb6 37. Nd4 Nc7 38. Nf3 Kg8 39. e5 dxe5 40. fxe5 Ra2 41. Qb3 Rxb2 42. Qxb2 Nxc4 43. e6 Nxb2 44. exf7+ Kxf7 45. Rd7+ Re7 46. Rc2 Rxd7 47. Bxd7 Nd3 48. Bc8 Nxb4 49. Rb2 b5
comment: This ought to be a decisive advantage for Black: the two passed pawns are awfully hard to stop.

moves: 1. c4 e5 2. g3 g6 3. Bg2 Bg7 4. Nc3 Nf6 5. Nf3 d6 6. O-O O-O 7. d4 Nbd7 8. Qc2 Re8 9. Rd1 exd4 10. Nxd4 a5 11. e4 Nc5 12. f3 c6 13. Be3 Qe7 14. Bf2 Nfd7 15. b3 Ne5 16. h3 Ned7 17. Rd2 Bh6 18. Re2 f6 19. f4 Nf8 20. Rd1 Bd7 21. Ree1 Rad8 22. a3 Bc8 23. b4 axb4 24. axb4 Nce6 25. Nde2 Qc7 26. Qb3 Kh8 27. Rc1 Qf7 28. Na4 Nc7 29. Nb6 Qg8 30. Nxc8 Rxc8 31. Qc2 Nd7 32. Red1 Bf8 33. Bd4 Ra8 34. h4 Qf7 35. Bh3 Ne6 36. Bb2 Nb6 37. Nd4 Nc7 38. Nf3 Kg8 39. e5 dxe5 40. fxe5 Ra2 41. Qb3 Rxb2 42. Qxb2 Nxc4 43. e6 Nxb2 44. exf7+ Kxf7 45. Rd7+ Re7 46. Rc2 Rxd7 47. Bxd7 Nd3 48. Bc8 Nxb4 49. Rb2 b5 50. Kg2 c5 51. Rd2 Nbd5 52. Bb7 Ke6 53. Re2+ Kd7 54. Nd2 c4 55. Ne4
comment: White's Ne4 & Bb6 help to corral Black's king and Black doesn't want to play ...f6-f5 which allows Ne4-g5xh7 and White counterplay.

moves: 1. c4 e5 2. g3 g6 3. Bg2 Bg7 4. Nc3 Nf6 5. Nf3 d6 6. O-O O-O 7. d4 Nbd7 8. Qc2 Re8 9. Rd1 exd4 10. Nxd4 a5 11. e4 Nc5 12. f3 c6 13. Be3 Qe7 14. Bf2 Nfd7 15. b3 Ne5 16. h3 Ned7 17. Rd2 Bh6 18. Bd4 Ra8 34. h4 Qf7 35. Bh3 Ne6 36. Bb2 Nb6 37. Nd4 Nc7 38. Nf3 Kg8 39. e5 dxe5 40. fxe5 Ra2 41. Qb3 Rxb2 42. Qxb2 Nxc4 43. e6 Nxb2 44. exf7+ Kxf7 45. Rd7+ Re7 46. Rc2 Rxd7 47. Bxd7 Nd3 48. Bc8 Nxb4 49. Rb2 b5 50. Kg2 c5 51. Rd2 Nbd5 52. Bb7 Ke6 53. Re2+ Kd7 54. Nd2 c4 55. Ne4 Be7 56. Rd2 Ke6 57. Re2 Kf7 58. Rd2 Ke6 59. Re2 Kf7 60. Rd2 Nb6 61. Nd6+ Ke6 62. Nxb5 Nxb5 63. Rb2 Bc5
comment: Shirov must have been in time pressure because this position still offers Black obvious chances to win.
